articles.headline: Squirming, but Watching a Dying Reality Star
articles.snippet: The crude-talking, hard-drinking Jade Goody, who struck a chord on “Big Brother,” wants to take reality TV to a new extreme.
articles.abstract: The crude-talking, hard-drinking Jade Goody, who struck a chord on “Big Brother,” wants to take reality TV to a new extreme.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Before television shined its warped light on her, Jade Goody was surely destined for a life of hardship and obscurity. Crude-talking, hard-drinking, overweight, barely educated, in debt, the child of drug addicts, she appeared on the reality show “Big Brother” in 2002 as a kind of token lowlife.

articles.headline: UBS Pressed for 52,000 Names in 2nd Inquiry
articles.snippet: A court filing raised questions about the scale of the Swiss bank’s efforts to help rich customers evade taxes.
articles.abstract: A court filing raised questions about the scale of the Swiss bank’s efforts to help rich customers evade taxes.
articles.lead_paragraph: The UBS memo was blunt: the “Swiss solution” could help affluent Americans.

articles.headline: The Global Recession, Graded on a Curve
articles.snippet: The United States economy and stock market are doing quite well compared to those of other countries.
articles.abstract: The United States economy and stock market are doing quite well compared to those of other countries.
articles.lead_paragraph: If the economies and stock markets of the world were graded on a curve, the United States would be doing quite well.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Finds Financier Suspected of Fraud
articles.snippet: The Texas financier Robert Allen Stanford was located in Virginia by federal agents, who served him with civil papers.
articles.abstract: The Texas financier Robert Allen Stanford was located in Virginia by federal agents, who served him with civil papers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Two days after he was accused of running an $8 billion financial fraud, the Texas financier Robert Allen Stanford was located by federal agents Thursday and served with civil papers in the case.

articles.headline: Lawmakers Seek to Return Right to Sue Device Makers
articles.snippet: A Supreme Court decision in 2008 barred lawsuits against makers of medical devices approved by the F.D.A.
articles.abstract: A Supreme Court decision in 2008 barred lawsuits against makers of medical devices approved by the F.D.A.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the same day last month that a federal judge in St. Paul threw out hundreds of lawsuits against the maker of a faulty heart device, a man entered a nearby hospital to have one of those flawed products surgically removed.

articles.headline: U.S. Tries a Trillion-Dollar Key for Locked Lending
articles.snippet: The Obama administration hopes to encourage new lending by effectively subsidizing the profits of firms that serve as bankers to the banks.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration hopes to encourage new lending by effectively subsidizing the profits of firms that serve as bankers to the banks.
articles.lead_paragraph: Credit cards, home equity lines, student loans, car financing: none come cheaply or easily in these credit-tight times. The banks, the refrain goes, just will not lend money.

articles.headline: Texas Town Holds Roots of Empire
articles.snippet: Robert Allen Stanford, accused of running an $8 billion fraud, kept up ties with the Texas hometown he left years ago.
articles.abstract: Robert Allen Stanford, accused of running an $8 billion fraud, kept up ties with the Texas hometown he left years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXIA, Tex.  When Robert Allen Stanford began planting the seeds of his multibillion-dollar financial empire decades ago, he turned to a family friend here in his hometown, population 6,600, to fill a seat on the board.

articles.headline: Its Muscle Car Glory Faded, Pontiac Shrivels Up
articles.snippet: The story of Pontiac is a case study of the missteps that helped put General Motors in its precarious state.
articles.abstract: The story of Pontiac is a case study of the missteps that helped put General Motors in its precarious state.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — With its history of building muscle cars like the GTO and the low-slung Firebird, Pontiac had good reason to take pride in its best-known marketing slogan from the 1980s, “We Build Excitement.”
